Project that blew my mind a bit earlier and I still think about often:

A Trustworthy, Free (Libre), Linux Capable,
Self-Hosting 64bit RISC-V Computer
https://contrib.andrew.cmu.edu/~somlo/BTCP/

This is an attempt to build a *completely* open source computer system, both software AND hardware.

On what level? Current SOTAs afaict:

sim only: NAND to Tetris.
breadboard/PCB: Ben Eater 8bit computer / MOS 6502
FPGA: something like the Self-Hosting 64bit RISC-V Computer, though it's not a "course", just an endpoint.
ICs:  Really wish to get around to TinyTapeout.

I wish colleges taught everything mentioned in this ~100-page paper for their computer architecture course.

The paper talks so much about cache, OS, threads, memory controller, and how the CPU juggles in between.

If you're in your 2nd or 3rd year and want to better understand

it is done.

The idea behind Apple Intelligence is a stroke of genius!

They built a large foundation model and fine-tuned it on multiple tasks.

But they are doing something very clever:

They built adapters they plug into the large model to fine-tune it on the fly for specific tasks.

yacine's guide to writing c (2 woe (weeks of experience) 

RULE NUMBER 1
Never, ever, use the heap. Allocate literally everything on the stack. Simply pre-reserve 1gb for buffers defined on your stack. If your users don't have enough RAM, they don't deserve to run your software.

> Make it easier to understand
> Refine the explanation in each iteration

*it seems hard at first but after a few iterations, the concept starts becoming clearer

Understanding Deep Learning

Impressive new book on understanding deep learning concepts. 

Topics include fundamental building blocks, Transformers, GNNs, RL, diffusion models, and more.

Probably one of the most comprehensive and up-to-date overviews of deep learning that exist

1/n: Ever wanted to build an operating system? 

xv6 is a modern re-implementation of Dennis Ritchie's and Ken Thompson's Unix Version 6 (v6) for RISC-V multiprocessors, using ANSI C. Developed by MIT, it is designed to teach fundamental OS concepts.

It's a tool for simulating federated learning, and it has support for local training with MLX.

Docs: https://apple.github.io/pfl-research/

You know I say "Don't learn Languages, learn Programming"? I can say the same about Text Editor. Don't learn Vim or Emacs. Learn how to Navigate by Searching, Rectangular Selection, Multiple Cursors, Macros, etc, etc. These are the concept applicable in any Self-Respecting Editor

How to start making programming languages.

1. Learn Assembly.
2. Write a program in your favorite language that converts your favorite language to Assembly.

Does not have to be the full language. Just a tiny subset. Maybe only a "Hello, World". That'll get you started.

which self-learning method is more effective

1. Grab an array of curriculum and iteratively process every element from start to finish (Linear Learning)

2. Pick a good node and search all its surrounding nodes until you get a rough grasp of what's going on (Graph Learning)

What is a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE)?

A Mixture of Experts (MoE) is a machine learning framework that resembles a team of specialists, each adept at handling different aspects of a complex task. 

It's like dividing a large problem into smaller, more manageable parts and assigning
